awd_abstract_narration:
In the U.S. and many other countries people are increasingly putting off starting families until later in life. Correspondingly there is growing concern about the effects of mothers' and fathers' ages on the biology of their offspring. This research examines an important genetic marker of aging, telomere length, that is thought to be influenced by paternal age.  Telomeres are DNA that cap the ends of chromosomes, and that shorten with cell replication, oxidative stress, and age.  Contrary to other findings, older paternal age might have positive influences on telomere length that promote offspring longevity. This proposal will collect family tree histories and measure telomere lengths in order to better discern whether paternal age actually influences telomere length, and whether this effect persists across generations (e.g. whether grandfather's age or great-grandfather's age at reproduction influences descendants' telomere lengths). Additionally this proposal will examine whether telomere length influences early life immune function in addition to aging. These investigations will therefore contribute to the larger understanding of the evolution of human life history. Broader impacts include the production of a valuable shared dataset that will be relevant to human biologists and public health researchers, and integration of the project analysis and data into student training, mentoring and curricula. 

Models for the evolution of senescence assume that when individuals reproduce at advanced ages, selection will favor increased maintenance effort and a corresponding slowing of senescence. Inter-specific comparisons and selection experiments in model organisms have demonstrated that lower mortality/later ages of reproduction are associated with lifespan extension, broadly supporting these theoretical expectations. While natural selection operating on gene frequencies is assumed to form the basis of much of this variation, recent work in telomere biology provides evidence for a mechanism of intergenerational plasticity that could lead to rapid changes in maintenance effort in response to shifts in reproductive scheduling. Telomere shortening places limits on cell division, and is thought to contribute to impairment of cell proliferation-dependent traits such as immunity and tissue repair, and thereby to accelerate senescence. Unlike the telomere length (TL) attrition that occurs with age in most tissues, sperm are the only cell type in which TL increases with age. Because telomeres are DNA, any lengthening of sperm TL due to delayed reproduction should be passed on to offspring with high fidelity, leading to the hypothesis that multi-generational secular trends towards older paternal age at conception (PAC) will result in cumulative and rapid lengthening of inherited TL. Although PAC in any one generation will vary due to birth order and other factors, the cumulative multi-generational character of the PAC effect could lead to a more stable, and thus reliable, indicator of age at reproduction in recent ancestors--thus providing a useful signal from which to calibrate patterns of resource allocation that influence the pace of aging. Recent pilot data demonstrated this cumulative PAC effect across two generations living in Cebu, the Philippines. However, it remains unclear how many generations the PAC effect on TL persists, and thus, how deep and integrative the historical demographic signal conveyed via TL is. This project will therefore 1) examine the intergenerational stability of the PAC effect on descendants' TL across four generations; 2) characterize the sex-specific heritability patterns of TL; and 3) assess possible fitness impacts of inherited TL as reflected in early life infectious disease related morbidity and mortality.

por.por_cntn:
Telomeres are segments of DNA found at the ends of our chromosomes that cap and protect the chromosome (not unlike the plastic tips at the ends of shoelaces). Each time one of our cells replicates telomeres get shorter, and thus telomeres throughout most of the body tend to get shorter as we age. When telomeres get too short, the cell can no longer replicate and sometimes dies. Thus, short telomeres are considered one contributing cause of the functional decline and health problems that often accompany aging.

 

Although we know that telomeres tend to shorten with age, individuals differ in the lengths of telomeres that they inherit from their parents at birth, and also in the rate at which they shorten with age.  The causes of this variation in telomere length are not well understood. Telomere length is a heritable trait, for which environmental factors such as infection, oxidative stress and psychosocial stress also contribute, but in poorly understood ways. Most studies of human telomere biology have been conducted among inhabitants of wealthy, western and industrialized countries.  Such populations represent a small fraction of human ecological and genetic diversity, which may limit our insights into the determinants of telomere length and the pace of telomere shortening.  As one prominent example, the low levels of early life infectious diseases that these populations often experience may minimize immune cell proliferation, and thereby place minimal stress on telomere shortening. 

 

In this NSF-funded study, we explored the determinants of telomere lengths and their consequences by building on a unique longitudinal study in the Philippines that has followed a large group of individuals from gestation to young adulthood, along with their older mothers (the Cebu Longitudinal Health and Nutrition Survey; CLHNS). We conducted additional surveys, blood collections and telomere length analysis from these blood samples. Importantly, we not only acquired additional longitudinal data which will be broadly useful for answering a variety of scientific questions, but also for the first time in the 35 year history of the study we collected information and blood samples from the older fathers’ generation.

 

Results so far have shed new light on 1) The inheritance patterns of telomere length and 2) Stress  determinants of telomere length.

 

1. Previous studies have shown that children of older fathers have longer telomeres (probably because as a man ages, telomeres in his sperm lengthen – a rare exception to the general tendency for telomere shortening with age). Past pilot data of ours showed for the first time that this happens across at least two generations: older fathers not only have offspring with longer telomeres, but their sons also have offspring with longer telomeres. That is, having an older grandfather on your dad’s side at the birth of your father predicts that you will have longer telomeres. In this study we extended this finding with a considerably expanded sample size and showed that the effect of fathers existed both for maternal and paternal grandfathers and is very likely caused by sperm telomere lengths progressively increasing with age. This implies that having a father and/or grandfather who reproduced at later ages might cause you to experience a slower pace of functional decline, and possibly even live longer, because you will be are born with longer telomeres. This might be an evolutionary mechanism which allows the offspring to receive a signal of what the environment was like in recent generations. If your father and grandfathers were able to live to reproduce at a later age it might be beneficial for you to invest in the repair processes that slow your own aging.

 

2. The first study to find an association between shortened telomeres and psychosocial stress, conducted in 2004, examined caregiving stress and the chronicity of care. It proved to be a seminal publication, inspiring broad explorations of the extent to which telomere length is a marker for the impact of psychosocial stress on health (it has been cited almost 2,500 times). The original study was of only 58 women and most other replication studies have also focused on few subjects. We analyzed newly-collected data on caregiving and telomere length. Despite our large sample of 1,233 individuals, we failed to find that caregiving predicted telomere length. While there is strong evidence that caregiving for a chronically disabled family member is bad for health, our work suggests that telomere length is unlikely to be an important contributing factor in these relationships.

 

These findings contribute to larger areas of research on life history theory, inter-generational epigenetic inheritance, aging and the developmental origins of health and disease. By clarifying these issues using longitudinal comparative data, this study holds promise to shed light on an important influence on contemporary global health problems and may inspire new approaches to understanding life-course influences on aging.
